conclusion: Consider initial direction of car, positions of blocks, and effects of collisions and deflections.
Car A is positioned near the bottom right of the image, facing towards the left.
The car is likely to first collide with the blue block directly in front of it.
Assuming a typical collision effect, the car will transfer some of its momentum to the blue block, potentially moving it slightly.
The car may continue moving forward or be deflected depending on the angle and force of the collision.
After the first collision, the car might continue towards the orange block nearby, depending on the deflection angle.
If the car is deflected upwards, it might encounter the green block above the blue one.
The car will eventually stop after transferring enough momentum to the blocks or if it encounters a block at an angle that halts its movement.

Potential second collision is either with the orange block or the green block, depending on deflection.
Stopping point is likely near the initial collision area, as multiple blocks are clustered together, which can absorb the car's momentum.
